text: hello everyone and thank you for being

going to talk about uh the work that we
did in analyzing the software security
of the rpai protocol tool set and like
the title of our talk suggests we sadly
do not come bearing good news so the
first part of the talk we're first going
to introduce a little bit what rpai is
and why we should care about it it's
still a pretty new protocol called so
it's uh necessary to kind of uh take it
uh from the top a little bit uh then
we're going to talk about the tools and
the methodologies that we had to develop
from scratch to do the uh security
analysis we will introduce the results
and at the end we will share some
colorful interactions that we had during
the disclosure
process so before we talk about RPI
specifically we have to uh very quickly
go back to another protocol that we all
know which is bgp bgp is the core
interdomain routing protocol that we
have it's the glue that keeps the
internet together but it is quite
vulnerable and it is vulnerable because
at the time when bgp was first developed
uh in
1989 the priorities When developing
these protocols were things like
efficiency and speed but not security
because the internet back then was much
smaller and used by much less uh
entities and uh the internet developed
in a way that was uh in a way
incompatible with the systems back then
and bgp still doesn't have security
guarantees and it is vulnerable to a
variety of attacks all of which come
with a pretty hefty price tag so the
community decided to do something to
protect uh bgp and of the many protocols
that were introduced over time RP seems
to be the one that's kind of winning the
race uh the rpai protocol is fairly new
it was first created in uh it was first
introduced sort of uh 15 years ago more
or less and in the past couple of years
alone it has uh seen very widespread
adoption major tier one providers in the
world are using rpai uh severals have
joined in big companies have also joined
the protocol as well to protect their
resources so it has been a pretty
successful protocol and its success has
been so uh widespread and memorable that
even the FCC just a few months ago
actually they published a um
recommendation where among other things
they were uh recommending the use of the
rpai uh in in the entire internet
infrastructure in the United States so
for all isps and Broadband in the
US and um next we're quickly going to go
over a little bit how the rpai works
because this is important context for
the rest of the talk um in this slide we
see the representation of the the
autonomous um system as a cloud with a
bgp router in it and here comes the
first half of the RPI infrastructure
which is the rpai repositories they are
a set of repositories all distributed uh
all in a way connected with one another
in a treel like way and it's important
to note that the root of any rpai
repository tree there must be one of the
five Regional internet registries that
that's important because the content of
these repositories has to be U
cryptographically verifiable data but we
don't we are not just interested in
verifying uh the Integrity of the data
but also the source of this information
because then all this information is
going to be used to make better routing
decisions and of all the data that RP
repositories have Raa is the one that's
most important for us at this point the
raw is a file that contains a tle with a
network prefix and an autonomous system
number that is allowed to announce this
prefix on the internet and this is the
content that is then going to be used to
uh inform better routing now I said a
lot of things here we have repositories
you have to download data and you have
to do that relatively often because data
is changed or things are updated you
have to uh parse multiple files and do
cryptographic validation all of this is
stuff that routers generally don't like
to do so all of this has been outsourced
to the relaying party which is
technically Tech Al the second half of
the rpai infrastructure and the engine
of the RP it does all the forementioned
stuff and in the end it generates a
master file that contains all of these
prefix autonomous system number tles
that have been verified sends them over
to the router and now the router is a
little bit smarter than it used to be
now it's able to tell um a part between
valid bgp announcements and uh potential
uh hijacking attacks or bgp leaks
so one thing to sort of take away from
this setup is that the reing party is a
piece of software that has to be always
available it has to have an ongoing
connection with a router and if
something were to happen to that
connection routers will eventually flush
all the data that they have because they
cannot guarantee their freshness and as
a result become again vulnerable to
attacks so uh Nicholas and I are PhD
students which means our day job is
essentially pi a protocol pick a program
and try to break it and that's what we
decided to do with the relay party
implementations out there and what we
did was we took uh two fairly popular
implementations we uh started tinkering
with them a little bit and the result
was we were able to crush them uh by
using just fairly simple manipulations
and the next step was we wanted to
quantify how many entities would
actually be be affected by the crashes
that we found maybe it was a neg ible
amount it was almost 85% of all relaying
parties that had been at the time
deployed in the world that could be
crashed with the vulnerabilities that we
found and so at this point after finding
such uh big issues uh with just uh some
very rudimentary manipulations we
decided that it was time to do some
systemic analysis because if we could
find something so big with just uh you
know easy tinkering maybe a systemic
analysis would provide us with more
issues and at this point I'd like to
hand it over to Nicholas who's going to
tell us more yes uh thank you donica
right so this is already bad right
because we have two vulnerabilities
which are quite easy to find and affect
a lot of clients and this sparked our
interest because if you have such easy
to find vulnerabilities how much could
you find when you actually started
looking so at this point we started to
think about how we could conduct a more
systemic analysis of the implementations
and we quickly landed on fuzzing as the
most promising solution for this because
fuzzing is supposed to be easy to set up
you can test a lot of implementations at
once and you can hopefully find a lot of
problems especially because denial of
service is already a big problem so
finding a crash is already sufficient
for a
vulnerability and at this point when we
start to think about it we thought this
will probably be quite simple we use
existing software we run a fuzzer we
find a lot of vulnerabilities and then
we can publish our results now if this
is so easy why has nobody done it why
were there so easy to find
vulnerabilities in the rpki and that's a
good question and we didn't know so we
started to look into it and we made our
plan which we thought would be simple so
we wanted to use existing software the
most suitable fuzzer install it use it
to generate inputs and find crashes
right so I made a little sketch here to
visualize what we were planning so on
the left we have a person representing
the fuzzer and on the right we have the
relying party implementation uh
represented by an quite instable house
and now the fer will start to generate
objects throw them at the RP and Trigger
some sort of error message error code
whatever some sort of indication what
happened and we'll use this indication
to generate the next object and throw it
at the RP again trigger some different
error message and keep going until at
one point it finds an input which
crashes the RP and this is nice because
when we can crash the RP we have already
found a
vulnerability okay so so far on our
Simple Plan it turned out that reality
wasn't as simple as we had hoped because
when we started to implement this when
we downloaded the fuzzer we down
downloaded the RPS we started running it
we noticed that we run into a problem
because when we started the fuzzer it
will generate objects it will throw them
at the RPS and we would get our first
error me message which fair enough some
error message within the parsing logic
of the RP now we kept the fuzer running
of course and it turned out that we
would always basically get the same
error the object that the fuzer
generated would always fail very early
within the validation or the parsing
logic of the relying party and we just
couldn't get it to find any
vulnerability whatsoever it was just
always getting stuck very early in the
processing now at this point we got a
little bit frustrated because we already
spent weeks on this and we just couldn't
get it to run at all and then we looked
into it and we looked into the rpki
objects because that's what the fuzer is
generating it generates objects rpki
objects which are input into the relying
party and it turns out that RP objects
are very complex so as uh rpki uses the
asn1 language to define the objects you
might know it from other protocols for
example in TLS you will also have asn1
defined objects um common format is the
x509 certificate format and in fact rpai
also uses this format but the each rki
object contains a x509 sta certificate
it also contains other data so the
objects are even more complex than x509
certificates and that's the reason why
our fuzzer wasn't able to produce any
results because the objects are so
complex that the fuzzer just wasn't able
to get close enough to how the objects
should look like to get anywhere in the
parsing so I brought an example of a
real world AP object here it's a rower
uh or a certificate sorry um and you
might it might be difficult to see on
the monitors but it's basically 2
kilobytes of data and you have a lot of
structure information so you for example
have lists and you have sets and you
have lists within lists and so on so
these objects are very complex now this
problem by itself would have been
solvable for example by using the
structure aware fuzzer but things get
worse because apai use a technology
which makes fuzzing very very difficult
and that technology is
cryptography now cryptography is very
nice because it allows you to for
example create a digital signature of
the content of an object this is nice
because it attests that the content
hasn't been changed but the entire thing
that a fuzz is doing is changing the
content of the objects right so with the
signatures and in fact every API object
is signed and most of most of them even
have two signatures to make it more fun
um
now with the signatures the F struggles
because it will always automatically
break the signature once it changes the
content of the object and so even if
parsing succeeds it will always fail
very early in the
validation now at this point we got very
frustrated because we just couldn't
figure out how we could get it to run
and in the end there was only one option
left to us which was we had to build one
ourselves we had to build our own fer
because
how hard can it actually be well it
turns out it can be very hard so we
spent nine months on this and we wrote
over 20,000 lines of rust code until we
finally had something which we could
work with and humble as we are we called
our tour cure and in the next slides I
want to go a little bit over the inner
workings of cure and show how we solve
the challenges that I brought up and
let's start with the first challenge
with the complexity of the object
objects and how to generate them now we
implemented two different object
generation modules the first we
implemented was random bite mutation the
concept is quite simple you use an
existing RP object and you just mutate
it randomly so you will add bites you
will remove bites you will swap bites
and you don't care about the structure
you just change the bites in the
objects and this part is very good to
find vulnerabilities within the parsing
logic of the Reliant parties now the
second thing we implemented was the
structure aware mutation part and this
module basically we implemented the
entire logic of how RPI objects look
like which was very fun and um it will
generate objects which are completely
parsible which means these objects don't
feel uh don't fail in the parsing stage
but will get through to validation and
then can find vulnerabilities within the
validation um pipeline of the relying
parties
and in the end it turned out that we
needed both of these because with both
we could find vulnerabilities which the
other couldn't find and in total we
found 18 vulnerabilities within the
relying
parties now let's get to the second
solving the Second Challenge the
cryptography so um cure implements a
module which we called repository F and
this module takes the generated object
independent of which of the object
generation modules we used and it will
adapt it according to what we need so it
will do all the cryptographic operations
so recompute all the signatures and it
will also add all other necessary Fields
within the object so for example within
a rower object you have I think like 15
fields which need to be adapted which
for example is the fingerprint of the
parent or the name of the parent or the
location of the object all of these
fields need to be adapted for the
relying party to even begin the
processing and this will all be done
within this module and after the
adaption of the object it will be placed
within a valid rpki repository and it
will be made available to all the
relying parties that we want to test and
that's a big benefit of our setup it's
not implementation specific so you can
connect an arbitrary implementation of
an rpki relying party and it will be
tested with our setup and with this we
finally have a setup which works for
fuzzing ring parties and with this I
will hand back over to Don who will talk
about what we have
found thank
you so after developing cure we had to
test it against something and we didn't
want to just pick arbitrary
implementations on the internet just for
uh the sake that they were some really
part implementation we wanted to
actually test the implementations that
were being used by companies on the
internet and so we did a measurement
where we uh found out which were the
reling parties people were actually
using and in the slide here you can
actually see the list so all of the um
reling parties or all of the uh columns
in blue they are the actively maintained
at the time relay parties that were
being used and after letting cure run on
them for a couple of
weeks we found issues on three out of
these four actively maintained relay
parties in total 18 vulnerabilities of
which which five uh were be eventually
became
cves now the first vulnerability type
that we found was the path traversal
which affected the rou inator
implementation and if you recall uh from
this earlier slide rou inator is by far
the most widely used relay party so the
fact that it was vulnerable to path
traversal attack is pretty huge problem
and it was also rated at 9.3 by the
vendor in terms of criticality the the
cve and the the main issue with this
particular vulnerability is that there
were two ways you could exploit the path
traversal so in the first way is the
typical pth traversal exploitation you
take a bad file you put it in a place
where it's not supposed to be and you
try to take control of the host for
example the other way you could exploit
the path traversal is by poisoning the
relay party data so poisoning the data
that is then going to be uh sent over to
the router this was possible for some
version under certain conditions so not
on all implementations but it was a
possibility in some cases which is what
made this a particularly bad
issue the other type of vulnerability
that we found was just the ability to
pretty much dos the reling parties
crashed them and this was something that
we found for all the three vulnerable
relaying parties on multiple parts of
the source code so rator ekai Fort were
vulnerable and the way to exploit this
particular vulnerability in Rel partis
is essentially Rel pars have to
periodically do the whole download
process create the master file that is
sent to the routers but if for some
reason every time they Boot and they try
to download the data and they fail
without finishing the entire process
they're not going to be able to
establish a connection or create that
Master file to send over to the routers
and eventually stop the communication
with them so we call that stucking the
relaying parties in a in a Perpetual
fail and restart mode and this is what
the do vulnerabilities could cause so we
found these vulnerabilities and we
decided to evaluate how many relay
parties out there would be vulnerable to
those that we found and this is what it
looked like in May 2023 so last year uh
82.8% of all relay parties on the
internet were vulnerable to at least one
of the issues that we found now before
coming to black hat we decided to rerun
these measurements and see how things
have evolved in one year and uh we rean
these measurements in on the 30th of
July 2024 so last week I think and this
is what it looks like it's better but
it's not as good as one would hope there
is still 41.2% of all relaying parties
that people are using that are unpatched
not upgraded and therefore still
vulnerable to things that we discovered
and disclosed since last year and for a
protocol that is on the cusp of becoming
sort of a standard for routing security
this is not good practice this is not
good
news so because bad things come in
threes we also have another problem that
we found so as we were running all of
these tests with cure we were operating
in a closed system we had a isolated
test bed and sometimes we found that we
were creating objects that we were
feeding to all the relaying parties at
the same time no crashes were happening
no errors were being logged uh in the
log files but the really part is were
all giving us different results
different outputs and we checked the
code we checked the implementations and
what we eventually found out was that
for those processing steps that were not
very strictly defined or explained in
the standard the different vendors had
taken the Liberty to uh be creative in
how they were going to do the processing
so the next step was to check if these
inconsistencies were also present on the
internet or were they just triggered by
some uh very obscure path that our
father was
Finding and this is how it looked like
at the time and Frankly Speaking even if
you were to run the same experiment
today you would find the same situation
so Global inconsistencies were in fact
present on the internet no two relaying
parties are going to give you the same
exact output in sometimes this discre
these discrepancies amount up to several
thousands and again we decided deed to
look into why this was exactly happening
so we repurposed cure a little bit we
changed it in order to do this
differential analysis of the actual RPI
data on the internet
and one of the um examples that we're
going to show which is the most
egregious one is the Amazon example so
Amazon did all the right things it was
protecting its prefixes it issued Ras it
was doing everything according to the
book but one particular implementation
was being a bit finicky so one
implementation had a very strict set of
headers that it was allowed in the in
the certificates of the RPI objects if
for some reason the certif the
certificate included a header not in
that very strict list it would discard
the entire certificate and in this
particular case Amazon had the
organization name header in their
certificates a pretty benign header very
commonly used but for one implementation
this was a deal breaker they would
discard it entire certificate and
because of the cryptographic nature of
the objects in the RPI repositories if
you discard the certificates you're
going to also discard all the uh
Associated objects with it which
included a bunch of Ras which led to uh
6,45 prefixes in Amazon not being
protected by all of those entities that
were using this particular uh
implementation of course we also found
other instances but the effect of those

this was the biggest situation that we

yes thank you right so after finding all

ticket we tried again one month later
and the same thing happened within hours
they closed our ticket and we kept going
we kept sending new emails and always
the same thing would happened would
happen until at one point we wrote to

within the next days please fix it and
still nothing they still closed the
ticket and then months later we checked
their repository for a different
research project and then they had
archived it so they deprecated the
software without telling us which
confused us a little bit because also
most of the vulnerabilities we found
would have been quite easy to fix and if
they would have asked we would also have
helped them right yeah but I guess they
didn't want to now the learning for us
at this point was that it was still good
that we kept trying because at one point
at least we achieved deprecation which I
guess is better than nothing because
then people can change what they're
using and not be vulnerable anymore to
the
problems and with this let's come to our
conclusion so the first takeaway from
our research is that rpki is a core
Internet Security protocol and it's
getting continuously more deployed and
it's actually quite good so if anyone is
using bgp maybe is the network admin in
this room think about using rpki because
the technology has really evolved and is
really very good but the software
majority in places is partially not yet
production ready um but it is getting
there now the second takeaway is that
patches do not come as fast as we would
like so some vendors might not patch at
all and others um will patch but only
very late and as Don explained we saw
still almost half of the RPS on the
internet still vulnerable so if anyone
here um is running their own RP then
please patch your software because the
vulnerabilities are actually quite
severe and the last takeaway from our
work is that fuzzing cryptography is
very hard and it's hard because it's
complex but complexity also leads to
vulnerabilities and usually cryptography
is used in places where you really want
security so we need more tools that look
into the security of these cryptographic
protocols and maybe even need more
fuzzes which are built to test the
security and resilience of these
protocols and with this we're at the end
of our presentation um if you have any
